name: Brady, Christopher D.
title: Co-Founder and Managing Director
notes: Previously spent 14 years in Corporate Finance and Capital Markets at Lehman Brothers and Dillon Read & Co. before co-founding The Chart Group in 1994 and Chart National in 2018. Chart National focuses on the Defense, Security and Intelligence sector.

name: Brady, Nicholas F Jr.
title: Former U.S. Secretary of the Treasury (1988-1993); former U.S. Senator, New Jersey (1982); former Chairman and CEO, Dillon Read & Co.
political_donations: Republican donor; longtime Thoroughbred horse owner and breeder; joined Wild Horse Observers Association (WHOA) board.
ngos: Wild Horse Observers Association (WHOA); Hoover Institution (Guest Contributor)
notes: 68th U.S. Secretary of the Treasury under Presidents Reagan and Bush (1988-1993). Appointed U.S. Senator from New Jersey in 1982 to fill Harrison Williams's vacancy. Architect of the Brady Plan (Brady Bonds) to resolve 1980s developing-country debt crisis. Prior career: 34-year investment banking career at Dillon Read & Co., serving as CEO for 17 years. Born April 11, 1930; as of 2026 is the oldest living former U.S. Senator.

name: Farrell, James T.
title: Managing Partner and Co-Founder
notes: Co-founded Calera Capital in 1991, a San Francisco-based private equity firm that has invested over $5 billion in equity capital focused on middle-market companies in business services, logistics, and specialty industrials. Previously an Associate at ESL Partners and began career at Copley Real Estate Advisors. A.B. from Princeton University; M.B.A. from Harvard Business School.

name: Lathrop, Thomas N.
notes: Public records indicate Thomas Nash Lathrop lives in San Francisco, CA. Background may include investment/advisory work in the San Francisco Bay Area.

name: McClary, Edward Bertrum
notes: Public records indicate Ed McClary resides in San Francisco, CA.

name: Metz, Thomas F
title: Advisory Board Member; Retired U.S. Army Lieutenant General
ngos: Trident University International (Board Member); Intelligent Waves Advisory Board
notes: Retired U.S. Army Lieutenant General with over 40 years of active service. Graduated from West Point in 1971. Commanding General, III Corps and Fort Hood (2003). Commanded Multi-National Corps-Iraq during Operation Iraqi Freedom (2004-2005), leading over 120,000 coalition troops. Final assignment: Director, Joint Improvised Explosive Device Defeat Organization (JIEDDO), with $4 billion annual congressional budget. Retired January 2010. Holds M.S. in Mechanical Engineering from North Carolina State University.

name: Miller, O'Malley M.
employer: Allen Matkins Leck Gamble Mallory & Natsis LLP
title: Partner
ngos: American College of Real Estate Lawyers (Fellow)
notes: Partner at Allen Matkins (Los Angeles), one of California's top real estate law firms. Previously head of the real estate practice at Munger, Tolles & Olson LLP. Consistently ranked among top real estate lawyers in California by Chambers & Partners USA and listed in The Best Lawyers in America every edition since 1987. Advises institutional investors, developers, and lenders on real estate finance, acquisitions, and development.

name: Mills, Alden M.
title: Founder and former CEO, Perfect Fitness; Author; Keynote Speaker
notes: Former Navy SEAL platoon commander (3x platoon commander, ranked #1 each time; 12 years service). National Collegiate Champion rower, Gold and Silver medalist at the Olympic Festival. Founded Perfect Fitness, inventor of the Perfect Pushup (over 6 million units sold, over 40 patents worldwide); grew company to $95 million in sales in three years (Inc. 500 fastest-growing company). Bestselling author of Be Unstoppable, Unstoppable Teams, and Unstoppable Mindset.

name: Nikias, Chrysostomos L
title: President Emeritus and Life Trustee; Malcolm R. Currie Chair in Technology and the Humanities; Professor of Electrical Engineering
ngos: Synopsys, Inc. (Board Director, 2011-2023); College Football Playoff Board of Managers (Chair, 2015-2018); Alfred Mann Institute for Biomedical Engineering (Board, 2001-2018); American Academy of Arts and Sciences (Fellow)
notes: 11th President of USC (2010-2018). Born in Cyprus. Cypriot-American academic who led USC's emergence as a top-tier global research university. Led the largest fundraising campaign in the history of higher education at the time. Prior roles at USC: founding director of Integrated Media Systems Center, Dean of Viterbi School of Engineering, and Provost. Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering, SUNY Buffalo (1982). Forced to resign in 2018 amid sexual misconduct scandals involving USC faculty.

name: Olson, Eric T. USN (Ret.)
title: President and Managing Member
ngos: Iridium Communications Inc. (Board Director, since 2011); Palladyne AI (Board Director, since 2021); Under Armour Inc. (Board Director); Cyber Reliant Corporation (Board); Ocean Aero Inc. (Board); Global SOF Foundation
notes: Retired four-star U.S. Navy Admiral. Eighth Commander, U.S. Special Operations Command (USSOCOM) (2007-2011), leading over 65,000 personnel and managing $10+ billion annual budget. First Navy SEAL to be promoted to three- and four-star ranks. Participated in Battle of Mogadishu (October 1993); awarded Silver Star. Previously commanded Naval Special Warfare Development Group (DEVGRU). Graduated U.S. Naval Academy 1973; M.A. National Security Affairs, Naval Postgraduate School. Founded ETO Group LLC (independent national security consulting) after retirement in 2011.

name: Pierson, Peter O'Malley
title: Professor of History Emeritus; Lee and Seymour Graff Professor of History (retired)
ngos: Society for Spanish and Portuguese Historical Studies (member); American Historical Association (member)
notes: Born October 4, 1932. Historian specializing in early modern Spain. Professor at Santa Clara University from 1966 until retirement; Department Chair 1988-1992. Former Fulbright Fellow in Spain (1964-1966); NEH Fellow (1974). Author of Philip II of Spain (1975), Commander of the Armada (1989), and The History of Spain. Ph.D. from history; expertise in the Spanish Armada and Philip II.

name: Quinn, Blake
title: Chairman and former CEO
ngos: University of Southern California Board of Trustees (member since 1994)
notes: Became dealer principal of Quinn Company in 1979, his family's Caterpillar dealership founded in 1919. Served as Chairman, President and CEO of Quinn Group Inc. (Fresno, CA), the Caterpillar dealer covering central and southern California plus Arizona. In 2021, Parker Quinn (the founders' great-grandson) assumed control as Dealer Principal, CEO and President. B.S. from USC Marshall School of Business (1976).

name: Roberts, Andrew
title: Bonnie and Tom McCloskey Distinguished Visiting Fellow
notes: Baron Roberts of Belgravia (created Life Peer, November 1, 2022, on Boris Johnson's 2022 Political Honours list). British historian and journalist born January 13, 1963. Also Visiting Professor, War Studies Department, King's College London; Lehrman Institute Lecturer, New-York Historical Society. Author of Churchill: Walking With Destiny (2018, NY Times and Sunday Times bestseller), Napoleon the Great (winner: Grand Prix de la Fondation Napoleon, LA Times Biography Prize), Salisbury: Victorian Titan (winner: Wolfson Prize for History), The Storm of War (winner: British Army Book Prize). Member of the House of Lords.

name: Rogers, Joe W. Jr.
title: Chairman; former CEO
political_donations: Major Republican donor. FEC records show contributions to the Republican National Committee totaling ~$239,400 (2007-2016), National Republican Congressional Committee ~$19,500 (2009-2014), Georgia Republican Party ~$44,500 (1992-2016), and various Republican candidates and PACs. Total tracked political contributions exceed $400,000.
notes: Son of Waffle House co-founder Joe Rogers Sr. (who co-founded the chain in 1955 with Tom Forkner). Born 1950/1951. CEO of Waffle House since 1973; became Chairman. Under his leadership Waffle House grew into a ~$4 billion company; Rogers Jr. is a Forbes billionaire (est. net worth $1.7 billion). Known for conservative/Republican political giving. Chain is privately held and headquartered in Norcross, Georgia.

name: Squires, Kendall B. Mooers
title: Attorney (retired); former real estate and tax lawyer
notes: Born January 17, 1939 in Cincinnati, Ohio. Admitted to the California bar in 1967; admitted to U.S. Tax Court (1974) and U.S. Supreme Court. Practiced in real estate law, contracts, and litigation in Bonita, California. Served as UCAN board chairman.

name: Stamps, S. Roe IV
title: Founding Managing Director (retired); Senior Advisor
ngos: Georgia Tech Foundation (Trustee Emeritus); University of Miami (Trustee); John S. and James L. Knight Foundation (Trustee, chairs Investment Committee); National Venture Capital Association (former Director); Stamps Scholars Program (Founder)
notes: Co-founded Summit Partners in 1984 (global growth equity firm). Previously General Partner at TA Associates; Senior Investment Manager at First Chicago Investment Corporation. B.S. and M.S. in industrial engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology; M.B.A. with second-year Honors, Harvard Business School (1974). Prominent philanthropist: established the Stamps Scholarship Program at 24+ universities nationwide through the Stamps Family Charitable Foundation.

name: Starnes, Vaughn Alden MD
employer: Keck Medicine of USC / Children's Hospital Los Angeles
title: Chair, Department of Surgery; Surgeon-in-Chief, Keck Hospital of USC and USC Norris Cancer Center; H. Russell Smith Foundation Chair for Cardiovascular Thoracic Research; Founding Executive Director, USC Cardiac and Vascular Institute; Chief of Cardiothoracic Surgery, CHLA
ngos: American Association for Thoracic Surgery (100th President, 2019-2020)
notes: Pioneering cardiac and thoracic surgeon. Performed the first living-related double lobar lung transplant in 1993. Directed Southern California's first robotic heart operation (2001). Trained at Vanderbilt University (general surgery), Stanford University (cardiovascular surgery residency; chief resident in cardiac transplantation under Dr. Norman Shumway), and Hospital for Sick Children, London (pediatric cardiovascular surgery fellowship). Graduate of University of North Carolina School of Medicine.

name: Starr, S. Frederick
employer: Central Asia-Caucasus Institute, Johns Hopkins University SAIS
title: Founding Chairman; Research Professor, Johns Hopkins SAIS
ngos: American Foreign Policy Council (Senior Fellow); Nazarbayev University, Kazakhstan (Trustee); Institute for Security and Development Policy, Stockholm (Head of Advisory Council); National Bureau of Asian Research (Senior Fellow); Kennan Institute for Advanced Russian Studies (Founding Chairman)
notes: Born March 24, 1940. Former President of Oberlin College (1983-1994), President of the Aspen Institute, and Vice President of Tulane University. Founding Chairman of the Kennan Institute for Advanced Russian Studies at Woodrow Wilson International Center. Advised three U.S. presidents on Russian/Eurasian affairs. Co-authored first comprehensive strategic assessment of Central Asia and Afghanistan for the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Author of 20+ books including Lost Enlightenment: Central Asia's Golden Age (Princeton University Press, 2013). Jazz clarinetist; co-founded Louisiana Repertory Jazz Ensemble (1980). Ph.D., Princeton; M.A., King's College Cambridge; B.A., Yale.

name: Sutro, Stephen Sedgwick
title: Partner; Co-Chair, Trial Practice Group; former Managing Partner, San Francisco and Silicon Valley Offices
ngos: Bar Association of San Francisco, Criminal Justice Section (Executive Committee member); Northern California Chapter, Association of Business Trial Lawyers (Board of Governors)
notes: Fourth-generation San Francisco lawyer. Specializes in white-collar criminal defense, government investigations, securities fraud, antitrust, and complex civil litigation. Named Managing Partner of Duane Morris San Francisco office (2014); appointed Co-Chair of firm's Trial Practice Group (January 2024). Recognized as Northern California Super Lawyer (white-collar criminal defense) since 2012; named Top White Collar Lawyer by the Daily Journal (2024). J.D. cum laude, Santa Clara University School of Law (1994).

name: Texido, Michael
title: Managing Director and Wealth Advisor
notes: Based in Menlo Park, California. Over 27 years of experience in wealth management and financial services. Joined Cresset Capital as part of a team that moved from First Republic Investment Management (managing approximately $13 billion in assets). Previous roles: Senior Vice President and Advisor, Citi Family Office (Citigroup); Director, Credit Suisse First Boston (advised institutional money managers and hedge funds); Managing Director, Montgomery Securities. B.A. Cornell University; M.B.A. from Fuqua School of Business, Duke University.

name: Thornton, C. B. Jr.
title: President, Thornton Corporation; Member, Hoover Institution Board of Overseers
ngos: Hoover Institution Board of Overseers (Stanford University)
notes: Son of Charles Bates 'Tex' Thornton (1913-1981), founder of Litton Industries and one of the 'Whiz Kids' (Ford Motor Company). Thornton Corporation is in the aircraft maintenance business, based in San Marino, California. Sibling of William Thornton. Mother is Flora Thornton, prominent Los Angeles philanthropist. The Thornton Center for Engineering Management at Stanford University is named in honor of the Thornton family.
